title: BBC top 10 salary earners confirmed as pay cuts and boosts revealed for stars
body_text:
BBC's top 10 salary earners confirmed as pay cuts and boosts revealed for stars
The BBC has published the salaries of its highest-paid stars with Gary Lineker, Zoe Ball and Vernon Kay included in the top-paid stars
The BBC's top on-screen earners have been revealed, with cuts and boosts for some of the broadcaster's biggest stars.
As happens every year, the BBC has published the salaries of its highest-paid stars as part of its annual report, which also had a heavy focus on the recent Glastonbury Festival, the Gaza: How To Survive A Warzone documentary, and Gregg Wallace scandals.
On the money side, it was former Match of the Day presenter Gary Lineker, who recently left the corporation, who was once again the top earner with a take home salary of £1.35million.
He was followed by Radio 2 star Zoe Ball with £515,000 despite being replaced on the station's Breakfast Show by Scott Mills after hosting her last show at the end of last year.
Meanwhile, former footballer and Match Of The Day pundit Alan Shearer was the third-highest earner with a salary of between £440,000 and £444,999.
The former Newcastle United striker will continue to analyse football on the BBC in the new season with Match Of The Day’s incoming presenters Kelly Cates, Mark Chapman and Gabby Logan.
His pay also covered work on the BBC’s coverage of European football competitions, such as the UEFA Champions League, with the various gigs boosting his earnings by almost half a million pounds.
BBC Radio 1 Breakfast Show presenter Greg James came fourth on the list, earning between £425,000 and £429,999, for work which also included his Radio 4 show Rewinder, while Fiona Bruce and Nick Robinson were the joint fifth-highest earners, with both earning between £410,000 and £414,999.
Radio 2 host Vernon Kay joined the top 10 for the first time, earning £390,000, up from £320,000. Meanwhile, BBC Breakfast star Naga Munchetty received a boost to her pay, putting her in the top ten with £355,000, up from £345,000, but co-host Charlie Stayt's salary stayed the same
The top 10 earners this year are:
- Gary Lineker - £1.35million
- Zoe Ball - £515,000 - cut from £950,000
- Alan Shearer - £440,000 - up from £380,000
- Greg James - £425,000 - up from £415,000
- Fiona Bruce - £410,000 - up from £405,000 and Nick Robinson - £410,000 - up from £345,000
- Stephen Nolan - £405,000
- Laura Kuenssberg - £395,000 - up from £325,000
- Vernon Kay - £390,000 - up from £320,000
- Justin Webb - £365,000 - up from £320,000
- Naga Munchetty - £355,000 - up from £345,000
Just missing out on the top ten was Radio 2 presenter Scott Mills, earning £355,000-£359,999, up from £315,000 - £319,999 last year, having taken over the station's Breakfast Show at the start of the year.
A number of the BBC's on-screen talent doesn't feature in the publicly-funded BBC’s salary dossier, which discloses salaries above £178,000, because they are paid by external production firms or BBC Studios, the corporation’s commercial arm.
Many big names, including Strictly Come Dancing hosts Claudia Winkleman and Tess Daly, Graham Norton and Bradley Walsh do not feature for the same reason.
It comes as under-fire Director General Tim Davie received a £15k pay hike as he took home £540k. As the report was released, he said he can "lead" the BBC in the "right way" following a series of reputational scandals for the broadcaster.
The BBC has been criticised for a series of failings in recent months which included breaching its own accuracy editorial guidelines, livestreaming the controversial Bob Vylan set during Glastonbury, and recent misconduct allegations surrounding the MasterChef presenter Gregg Wallace.
